awd_titl_txt: Surface Science and Engineering Towards Bioactive Bulk Metallic Glasses
awd_abstract_narration:
The research objective of this award is to elucidate the mechanisms underlying the ion beam interactions with the bulk metallic glasses (BMGs) and the impacts of ion implantation on the surface bioactivity of BMGs. The research will (i) identify the key processes and variables for ion implantation towards bioactive BMGs, (ii) investigate the effects of ion implantation on both surface and electrochemical properties of BMGs, and (iii) study the biological activity of ion implanted BMGs, with a special focus relevant to the orthopedic applications of BMGs. These efforts will not only further our understanding of BMG-ion beam interactions, but also propel the advancement of BMGs as biomedical materials to address some of the unmet challenges in the orthopedic field, such as the bone tissue integration of implants.

If successful, the results of this research will provide an opportunity to create new functional and bioactive materials that are capable of forming direct biological bonding with cells through surface interactions. The results will be disseminated to enhance the scientific and technological understanding of BMGs, and to broaden BMG applications into biocompatible materials, which could potentially impact human health. The research will provide a unique opportunity for the PIs to educate and train graduate and undergraduate students in multidisciplinary areas of research, science, and engineering. Planned outreach activities include summer research program for teachers and pre-collegiate students to gain first-hand laboratory experience, and showcase of research endeavors at the interface of materials and biology in regional schools and local science museum.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Bulk metallic glasses (BMGs), also known as amorphous alloys, are materials with unique properties and of great interests for a number of applications, ranging from sporting goods to consumer electronics. Such materials have also drawn attentions from the biomedical field, which could potentially make good use of these materials for load-bearing orthopedic implants, for example. In an effort to propel the advancement of BMGs as biomedical materials in the orthopedic field, this project investigated surface modification of BMGs by the ion-implantation technique so that cell interaction with BMGs can be modulated. Our research revealed that, after low energy (i.e., 10 keV and 50 keV) Ar- or Ca-ion implantation, Zr-based BMGs were able to support a higher number of bone-forming MC3T3-E1 cells attached to the surface of the materials, and fluorescent staining of the adhered cells also showed greater biological contacts with the underlying substrates. Furthermore, both experimental and computational results demonstrated that the amorphous nature of the Zr-based BMGs was well preserved despite exposure to these ion-implantation processes, which is significant considering the amorphous microstructure of BMGs being key to the many remarkable properties of the materials. Improvement in electrochemical properties of BMGs was also observed for ion-implanted samples, a welcoming effect for such materials to be explored as long-term medical implants where the implant stability is of paramount significance. The project not only advanced our fundamental understanding of BMG-ion beam interactions, but also brought forward a versatile way to engineer the surface of BMGs to favor cell functions without compromising the amorphousness of the materials. Broader impacts included training of several graduate, and undergraduate students in multidisciplinary areas of research, science, and engineering, as well as introducing pre-collegiate students to the exciting interface of materials science and biology.


Last Modified: 08/24/2016
Modified by: Peter K Liaw
